attributes.title: Public Perceptions of the Role of International Organizations in Interstate Disputes

q1.value: Public Perceptions of the Role of International Organizations in Interstate Disputes

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This study evaluates the role of international governmental organizations (IGOs) for preventing the escalation of political disputes between states. It investigates whether different dimensions of IGOs’ involvement increase or decrease individuals’ approval of their home governments using force in a political dispute. Political science research suggests that IGOs reduce the occurrence of militarized conflict between states (Russett, Oneal, and Davis, 1998; Boehmer, Gartzke, and Nordstrom, 2004). But this research has highlighted a number of competing causal mechanisms, resulting in a variety of perspectives that make similar predictions but ultimately have different implications for the magnitude, timing, and effectiveness of IGOs’ ability to resolve interstate disputes, and for international relations in general. This project offers an approach to distinguish between different types of contributions IGOs can make toward preventing the escalation of political disputes. It tests whether different mechanisms behind IGOs’ potential influence on conflict resolution resonate to a different degree with members of the mass public. Members of the public are an important target audience for pacifying signals from IGOs. Because IGOs have limited influence over governments, a key channel for their influence on policy outcomes runs through domestic audiences (Dai, 2005; Pevehouse, 2005; Fang, 2008; Chapman, 2009; Thompson, 2010). Understanding if and how domestic publics perceive the impact of IGOs is therefore one central piece to the puzzle of identifying the specific contribution of IGOs to conflict resolution.

q16.value: Respondents who received the legality treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group. Respondents who received the brokering peace treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group. Respondents who received the costs of using force treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group. Respondents who received the legality treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group and the other treatments. Respondents who received the brokering peace treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group and the other treatments. Respondents who received the costs of using force treatment are less likely to support using force than respondents in the control group and the other treatments.

q17.value: I evaluate the potential impact of each mechanism (per the hypotheses above) in an online survey experiment. This survey experiment contains a short vignette describing a hypothetical political dispute between the respondent’s home country and a neighboring country. The vignette is kept similar to prior studies exploring individual attitudes toward the use of force in international conflicts (Tomz and Weeks, 2013; Dafoe, Zhang, and Caughey, 2015). The sample is recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk (AMT). Respondents are placed in three groups, one for each possible mechanism. In each group, they will either receive the group-specific priming statement or not, assigned randomly by the survey platform surveymonkey.com.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value: We will examine the "direction of change" distribution (see Bago & De Neys, 2017, Cognition) as function of complexity. We will also look for evidence of conflict detection through response latencies (final response) and confidence ratings as a function of complexity (initial and final response).

sample.value: We will test 100 participants via the Prolific Academic distribution platform.

analyses.value: We will calculate the proportion of correct initial and final responses as a function of problem complexity.

dependent.value: We use a two response paradigm in which participants first provide an initial, intuitive response and second, final response. We will look at accuracy, confidence ratings and response latencies at both response stages.

conditions.value: We use a within-subject design. All participants solve16 problems (3 easy conflict, 3 easy no conflict, 3 complex conflict, 3 complex no conflict and 4 fillers).

hypothesis.value: We examine boundary conditions of logical intuition among reasoners. We draw the hypothesis that for more complex inferences, it will be less likely that people will have an intuitive grasp of their logical structure. Consequently, logically valid fast inferences as well as conflict detection effects should be less likely with more complex inferences than with simpler ones.

q1.value: Systematic Review and Meta-analysis of Interventions to Improve Sun Protection in Primary School-Aged Children

q2.value: Meghan Halley, Anusha Kumar, Maya Mathur, Aydin Kaghazchi, Adam Cohen, Paige Wheaton Wolstencroft, Eleni Linos

q3.value: This is a systematic review and meta-analysis designed to summarize the current state of knowledge on interventions to improve sun protection for children ages 18 and under. The specific research question is: How effective are existing, systematic interventions for improving sun protection for children ages 18 and under?

q4.value: We will conduct a systematic review and meta-analysis to address the primary research question: “How effective are existing, systematic interventions for improving sun protection for children ages 18 and under?” We will specifically examine interventions designed to impact behavioral outcomes, including various objective measures of sun protective behaviors and sun exposure, as well as self-reported intention to take these behaviors. As a second objective, we will explore whether certain types of interventions have been more or less thoroughly explored in the current literature, and whether interventions with certain characteristics appear to be more or less effective in impacting outcomes across different age groups. In addition, we will evaluate risks of bias in this literature.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

attributes.title: Head Start Connects: Individualizing and Connecting Families to Comprehensive Family Support Services -- Case Studies
attributes.description: The Head Start Connects case studies will build knowledge about how Head Start programs coordinate family support services for parents/guardians and the processes or practices used to ensure that service coordination is aligned with individual family needs and fosters family well-being.

summary.value:
The Head Start Connects project aims to build substantial knowledge about how Head Start grantees, delegate agencies, and staff across the country coordinate family support services for parents/guardians and the processes or practices used to ensure that service coordination is aligned with individual family needs and fosters family well-being. The Head Start Connects project plans to conduct case studies at six Head Start sites across the U.S. in order to address the following research questions:

•	How do Head Start programs identify and assess individual family needs and develop 
individualized plans for family support services? 
•	How do Head Start programs link or refer families to family support providers and/or services? How do Head Start programs help families navigate services if multiple needs are identified? 
•	How do Head Start programs track service uptake, particularly for services delivered by community partners? How do programs determine whether referrals and/or services are meeting families’ needs? 
•	How do Head Start programs identify service providers in the community who provide family support services for parents and guardians? How do community needs assessments inform and affect how programs coordinate family support services? How are partnerships with service agencies developed and maintained? 
•	What are the facilitators and barriers to implementing a tailored approach to coordinating family support services at the family-, program-, and community-levels? What resources at the organizational or systems-level support coordinating family support services? 

Through interviews with up to 7 Head Start staff, 4 Head Start families, and 2 community providers at each of the six sites (up to 78 interviews total), the case studies will help describe key program activities for the coordination of family support services. The staff interviews will include a reflective case narrative where staff describe their work with different types of families and how they engage with families over time to coordinate family support services. 
 
The team will use insights from the case studies in the development of a national descriptive study of Head Start programs to understand how they coordinate family support services that are responsive to family needs.

•	How do Head Start programs track service uptake, particularly for services delivered by community partners? How do programs determine whether referrals and/or services are meeting families’ needs? 
•	How do Head Start programs identify service providers in the community who provide family support services for parents and guardians? How do community needs assessments inform and affect how programs coordinate family support services? How are partnerships with service agencies developed and maintained? 
•	What are the facilitators and barriers to implementing a tailored approach to coordinating family support services at the family-, program-, and community-levels? What resources at the organizational or systems-level support coordinating family support services? 

Through interviews with up to 7 Head Start staff, 4 Head Start families, and 2 community providers at each of the six sites (up to 78 interviews total), the case studies will help describe key program activities for the coordination of family support services. The staff interviews will include a reflective case narrative where staff describe their work with different types of families and how they engage with families over time to coordinate family support services. 
 
The team will use insights from the case studies in the development of a national descriptive study of Head Start programs to understand how they coordinate family support services that are responsive to family needs.

q1.value: Reducing Fish and Chicken Suffering: Harmful Beliefs

q3.value: This study, the first in our program of research dedicated to Reducing Fish and Chicken Suffering, will investigate the frequency and implications of beliefs held by the general population with respect to these animals (e.g., “chickens are not smart”, “fish don’t feel pain”). We will source the list of beliefs from a survey of advocates who work in this space. In addition to their frequency, we will examine how each belief is correlated with acceptance or rejection of two key appeals (counterbalanced): one asking people to reduce consumption of these species, one requesting support for welfare reform. This analysis will allow us to begin to identify which are the biggest barriers for institutional and individual campaigns. This study is a necessary first step before beginning experimental investigations so that we can target those investigations in promising areas.

q4.value:
We have no specific hypotheses. Rather, this is an exploratory study to determine which beliefs are most strongly associated with taking a pledge to reduce the consumption of either chicken or fish, and with agreeing to sign a petition to help the same animal.

We will also consider the role of demographics, diet, companion animal guardianship, and previous contact with chicken and fish to see if any are associated with our outcome variables or useful moderators of the above associations.

RQ1a: Which beliefs are most strongly associated with pledging to reduce consumption of fish?
RQ1b:  ...of chicken?

RQ2a: Which beliefs are most strongly associated with signing a petition to help fish? 
RQ2b: ...to help chicken?

RQ3: Which aspects of demographics, diet, companion animal guardianship, and previous contact with fish/chicken are most strongly associated with pledge-taking and willingness to sign a petition?

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: Participants are randomized to answer items relating to either chicken or fish, but solely to reduce participant burden.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: All participants will be recruited through Positly. Positly uses a subset of U.S. MTurk workers who have gone through additional screening measures to ensure data quality, including checks on the quality of responses, to make sure responses are coming from real participants who meet the study criteria. All participants will be over 18 years of age.

q14.value: A sample size of 497 per animal allows for the detection of a small-to-medium effect size (rho = .16) with a power of .95 in a point-biserial correlation (critical t = 1.96). We have included an additional ~50 participants to account for exclusions due to poor data quality or the failure of attention-check questions.

question.value:
The dependent variables are 1) signing a pledge to reduce consumption for chicken or for fish, and 2) willingness to sign a petition to increase the welfare of chicken or fish. Participants who provided their opinions on fish will complete the fish outcome measures, and participants who provided their opinions on chickens will complete chicken outcome measures.

All measured variables can be seen in the attached survey instrument.

An exploratory factor analysis may be used to investigate how the opinion questions group together. The outcome variables may also be regressed on the resulting factors in order to help determine which grouping is most strongly associated.

RQ1a & b: Each chicken and fish belief will be correlated with pledging to reduce the consumption of that animal using a point-biserial correlation.

RQ2a & b: Each chicken and fish belief will be correlated with willingness to sign a petition to help that animal using a point-biserial correlation.

RQ3: Each demographic variable will be associated (using correlation, point-biserial correlation, chi-square or appropriate robust analog) with pledges and petition willingness.  Diet, companion animal guardianship, and previous contact with fish and chickens will also be associated with the DVs using the same types of analysis.

EFA: We may also conduct an exploratory factor analysis, where we determine how the fish and chicken opinions cluster. In that case, each of the DVs for each animal will be regressed on the resulting factors using a binomial logistic regression.

q20.value: In the case of an EFA and subsequent analyses, reverse-coded items will be recoded.

q21.value: We will use a critical p-value of .05 to determine statistical significance.  Because this is exploratory work, we will not correct alpha levels.

q22.value:
Quality checks will be used in accordance with Faunalytics’ data quality standards. In the case of duplicate responses, we keep the earliest complete response. Participants will be excluded from the study if they are under the age of 18 or if they fail a captcha designed to catch bots. 

Participants will also be excluded if any TWO of the following criteria are met: 

1) they fail a consistency check, attention check, or comprehension check, 
2) they fail an additional consistency, attention, or comprehension check, 
3) they complete the survey in less than one third of the median time, 
4) they can be characterized as having a duplicate IP address as another survey respondent, having a suspicious IP address (as determined by https://itaysisso.shinyapps.io/Bots/), or coming from outside the geographic location included in the desired sample.

q23.value: Because the study is on MTurk and there is no sensitive data being collected, we will make all closed-ended questions mandatory.

attributes.title: Incentivizing Mobile Money as a Financial Savings Instrument among Young Women in Tanzania

q1.value: Incentivizing Mobile Money as a Financial Savings Instrument among Young Women in Tanzania

q2.value: Peter Carroll | Flora Myamba | Daniel Nielson | Joseph Price | Philip Roessler | Wayne Sandholtz

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Even financially literate individuals often fail to save at optimal rates (Choi et al. 2003, Madrian and Shea 2001). The world’s poor, saddled with additional stressors that alter decision-making (Mani et al. 2013), also tend to save less than they say they would prefer (Banerjee and Duflo 2007, Collins et al. 2010). This disconnect between desired and observed savings rates may be driven in part by present bias (Strotz 1956; Bartels, Urminsky, and Frederick 2011). An extensive experimental and quasi-experimental literature documents attempts to create savings products which account for present bias, often by providing commitment devices (Thaler and Benartzi 2004; Ashraf, Karlan, and Yin 2006; Giné, Karlan, and Zinman 2010; Bryan, Karlan, and Nelson 2010). These commitment-based savings products, however, have largely failed to find broad market appeal; penalties for early withdrawal may deter potential participants who fear unforeseen circumstances. But present bias may play an important role in another part of the savings equation: the perception of interest. In theory, interest compensates savers at or above the rate at which they discount the future. However, present bias may distort this calculation and prevent people from making the initial decision to save. Meanwhile, other areas of behavioral economics that have received less attention in the savings literature may offer a particularly useful set of insights for savings product design: loss aversion and salience (Kahneman, Knetsch, and Thaler 1990; Finkelstein 2009; Stango and Zinman 2014; Goldin and Homonoff 2013). Individuals appear to value items that they already possess at above market value, and they also weigh losses significantly more than gains of the same magnitude and are willing to pay disproportionate costs – and accept greater risk – to avert losses than to achieve similar gains. Mobile network operators (MNOs) have hitherto been prohibited from offering interest in many jurisdictions. Since mobile money is the only interaction many people have with the formal financial system, this has made it difficult to examine the role of interest in how the very poor make savings decisions in the developing world. By distributing profits in a way comparable to paying interest, our MNO partner has found a way to circumvent this restriction. We hope this study will be one of the first of many to investigate how innovative ways to pay interest can help encourage savings through digital financial services (DFS). We propose a savings device that leverages present bias and loss aversion by framing accumulated future interest as a salient, lumpy bonus, to be deposited up-front in the saver’s account and to be lost in the event of early withdrawal. The saver can keep the upfront interest only by saving a specified amount over the pre-determined period of time. Because the retention of the upfront interest is contingent on saving, the account functions very similarly to a normal savings account from the practical perspective of the financial institution – in this case the mobile network operator (MNO) offering digital financial services (DFS). However, we anticipate that framing the interest as an upfront interest will activate savers’ loss aversion and motivate increased saving relative to a traditionally-structured savings account.

q16.value: Our study aims to address the core question of whether a loss-aversion-based savings account can motivate increased savings among recipients of quarterly cash transfers. The main hypotheses we are testing are: H1: the offer of an upfront interest savings account will increase savings relative to a traditional interest savings account and a messaging and training placebo. H1a: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in motivating savings among those with a minimal-level of mobile money acumen. H1b: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in motivating savings among participants who are the primary or sole-users of their mobile money accounts. H2: the offer of an upfront interest savings account will increase other usage of digital financial services (e.g., receiving and sending of remittances). H2a: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in inducing additional DFS use among those with a minimal-level of mobile money acumen. H2b: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in inducing additional DFS use among participants who are the primary or sole-users of their mobile money accounts.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses we are undertaking a large-scale randomized control trial on 2,300 young rural Tanzanian women. Study participants are all existing enrollees in Sauti, a quarterly cash-transfer program being implemented in Tanzania by Jhpiego and its partners. The aim of the quarterly cash-transfers of 70,000 TZS (~$32.00 USD) is to buffer the population from risky behavior and reduce HIV/AIDs and other sexually transmissible infections. (All participants in our study are 18 years of age and older.) To facilitate the cash transfers, each participant has received a basic mobile phone handset and a SIM card from one of Tanzania’s major mobile network operations. Among those participants who are interested in being eligible for a special mobile money savings program, we will randomly assign them to one of three groups: 1.) Upfront interest savings account treatment (N=~770): a front-loaded benefit of 7,000 Tanzanian Shillings (~$3.15 USD) if subjects commit to saving 10 percent of each quarterly cash transfer they receive over the course of 5 months. In other words, if participants agree to save 10% of each 70,000 TZS (~$32.00 USD) quarterly cash transfer they receive within a 5-month window (two transfers received; a total of 14,000 TZS or ~$6.30 USD savings), we will provide them with 7,000 TZS (~$3.15 USD) upfront (50% interest rate). 2.) Traditional interest savings account treatment (N=~770): a more traditionally structured savings account in which participants will receive the lump sum interest at the end of the 5-month period if they save 10 percent of each of three quarterly cash transfers they receive from Jhpiego within that 5-month period. That is, if they commit to saving the 14,000 TZS or ~$6.30 USD, we will pay them the 50% interest (7,000 TZS or ~$3.15) at the end of the savings period. 3.) Training and messaging placebo (N=~770): These participants are not eligible for any interest but will receive training and messaging that parallels the treatments, including an in-person meeting right before the cash transfer on the benefits of savings, and regular messages including right before they receive a quarterly cash transfer to remind them of importance of savings. To evaluate our main hypotheses and compare savings and DFS use across these three groups, the main outcome measures will be drawn from administrative data on mobile phone use provided by our MNO partner (one of Tanzania's main mobile phone companies). At the time of registration, we worked with our implementing partner Jhpiego to gain consent from all program participants to use their mobile phone data for research purposes. The main mobile phone outcomes we will use in our study includes: **savings levels at the end of the 5-month savings program period **default rates (how many fail to save or who use their upfront interest) **effects on frequency of other digital financial services activities **how much they save in the 5th and 6th cash transfer installments (1 and 4 months after the savings program concludes) **how much they save 6 months out from end of enrollment period We will measure these outcomes using data provided by our MNO partner via a weekly data transfer containing anonymized data on each participant’s mobile money balance at closing, weekly min, weekly max, weekly average, and weekly aggregate of mobile money transactions and amounts (sent and received and deposits and withdrawals). In addition, the data transfer will provide information on the interest payment amounts to each MSISDN per quarter. Because we are able to obtain both static measurements of account activity, as well as account activity across time, we will also be able to measure account fluctuations at frequent intervals across the study time-period. Finally, we will be able to measure account data at the moments of the Jhpiego unconditional mobile money transfer one- and four-months following the end of the program. These outcomes will help us answer questions about the longer lasting effects of savings inducements on behavior.

registration_responses.q1: Incentivizing Mobile Money as a Financial Savings Instrument among Young Women in Tanzania
registration_responses.q2: Peter Carroll | Flora Myamba | Daniel Nielson | Joseph Price | Philip Roessler | Wayne Sandholtz
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Even financially literate individuals often fail to save at optimal rates (Choi et al. 2003, Madrian and Shea 2001). The world’s poor, saddled with additional stressors that alter decision-making (Mani et al. 2013), also tend to save less than they say they would prefer (Banerjee and Duflo 2007, Collins et al. 2010). This disconnect between desired and observed savings rates may be driven in part by present bias (Strotz 1956; Bartels, Urminsky, and Frederick 2011). An extensive experimental and quasi-experimental literature documents attempts to create savings products which account for present bias, often by providing commitment devices (Thaler and Benartzi 2004; Ashraf, Karlan, and Yin 2006; Giné, Karlan, and Zinman 2010; Bryan, Karlan, and Nelson 2010). These commitment-based savings products, however, have largely failed to find broad market appeal; penalties for early withdrawal may deter potential participants who fear unforeseen circumstances. But present bias may play an important role in another part of the savings equation: the perception of interest. In theory, interest compensates savers at or above the rate at which they discount the future. However, present bias may distort this calculation and prevent people from making the initial decision to save. Meanwhile, other areas of behavioral economics that have received less attention in the savings literature may offer a particularly useful set of insights for savings product design: loss aversion and salience (Kahneman, Knetsch, and Thaler 1990; Finkelstein 2009; Stango and Zinman 2014; Goldin and Homonoff 2013). Individuals appear to value items that they already possess at above market value, and they also weigh losses significantly more than gains of the same magnitude and are willing to pay disproportionate costs – and accept greater risk – to avert losses than to achieve similar gains. Mobile network operators (MNOs) have hitherto been prohibited from offering interest in many jurisdictions. Since mobile money is the only interaction many people have with the formal financial system, this has made it difficult to examine the role of interest in how the very poor make savings decisions in the developing world. By distributing profits in a way comparable to paying interest, our MNO partner has found a way to circumvent this restriction. We hope this study will be one of the first of many to investigate how innovative ways to pay interest can help encourage savings through digital financial services (DFS). We propose a savings device that leverages present bias and loss aversion by framing accumulated future interest as a salient, lumpy bonus, to be deposited up-front in the saver’s account and to be lost in the event of early withdrawal. The saver can keep the upfront interest only by saving a specified amount over the pre-determined period of time. Because the retention of the upfront interest is contingent on saving, the account functions very similarly to a normal savings account from the practical perspective of the financial institution – in this case the mobile network operator (MNO) offering digital financial services (DFS). However, we anticipate that framing the interest as an upfront interest will activate savers’ loss aversion and motivate increased saving relative to a traditionally-structured savings account.
registration_responses.q16: Our study aims to address the core question of whether a loss-aversion-based savings account can motivate increased savings among recipients of quarterly cash transfers. The main hypotheses we are testing are: H1: the offer of an upfront interest savings account will increase savings relative to a traditional interest savings account and a messaging and training placebo. H1a: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in motivating savings among those with a minimal-level of mobile money acumen. H1b: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in motivating savings among participants who are the primary or sole-users of their mobile money accounts. H2: the offer of an upfront interest savings account will increase other usage of digital financial services (e.g., receiving and sending of remittances). H2a: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in inducing additional DFS use among those with a minimal-level of mobile money acumen. H2b: The offer of an upfront interest savings account will be more effective in inducing additional DFS use among participants who are the primary or sole-users of their mobile money accounts.
registration_responses.q17: To test these hypotheses we are undertaking a large-scale randomized control trial on 2,300 young rural Tanzanian women. Study participants are all existing enrollees in Sauti, a quarterly cash-transfer program being implemented in Tanzania by Jhpiego and its partners. The aim of the quarterly cash-transfers of 70,000 TZS (~$32.00 USD) is to buffer the population from risky behavior and reduce HIV/AIDs and other sexually transmissible infections. (All participants in our study are 18 years of age and older.) To facilitate the cash transfers, each participant has received a basic mobile phone handset and a SIM card from one of Tanzania’s major mobile network operations. Among those participants who are interested in being eligible for a special mobile money savings program, we will randomly assign them to one of three groups: 1.) Upfront interest savings account treatment (N=~770): a front-loaded benefit of 7,000 Tanzanian Shillings (~$3.15 USD) if subjects commit to saving 10 percent of each quarterly cash transfer they receive over the course of 5 months. In other words, if participants agree to save 10% of each 70,000 TZS (~$32.00 USD) quarterly cash transfer they receive within a 5-month window (two transfers received; a total of 14,000 TZS or ~$6.30 USD savings), we will provide them with 7,000 TZS (~$3.15 USD) upfront (50% interest rate). 2.) Traditional interest savings account treatment (N=~770): a more traditionally structured savings account in which participants will receive the lump sum interest at the end of the 5-month period if they save 10 percent of each of three quarterly cash transfers they receive from Jhpiego within that 5-month period. That is, if they commit to saving the 14,000 TZS or ~$6.30 USD, we will pay them the 50% interest (7,000 TZS or ~$3.15) at the end of the savings period. 3.) Training and messaging placebo (N=~770): These participants are not eligible for any interest but will receive training and messaging that parallels the treatments, including an in-person meeting right before the cash transfer on the benefits of savings, and regular messages including right before they receive a quarterly cash transfer to remind them of importance of savings. To evaluate our main hypotheses and compare savings and DFS use across these three groups, the main outcome measures will be drawn from administrative data on mobile phone use provided by our MNO partner (one of Tanzania's main mobile phone companies). At the time of registration, we worked with our implementing partner Jhpiego to gain consent from all program participants to use their mobile phone data for research purposes. The main mobile phone outcomes we will use in our study includes: **savings levels at the end of the 5-month savings program period **default rates (how many fail to save or who use their upfront interest) **effects on frequency of other digital financial services activities **how much they save in the 5th and 6th cash transfer installments (1 and 4 months after the savings program concludes) **how much they save 6 months out from end of enrollment period We will measure these outcomes using data provided by our MNO partner via a weekly data transfer containing anonymized data on each participant’s mobile money balance at closing, weekly min, weekly max, weekly average, and weekly aggregate of mobile money transactions and amounts (sent and received and deposits and withdrawals). In addition, the data transfer will provide information on the interest payment amounts to each MSISDN per quarter. Because we are able to obtain both static measurements of account activity, as well as account activity across time, we will also be able to measure account fluctuations at frequent intervals across the study time-period. Finally, we will be able to measure account data at the moments of the Jhpiego unconditional mobile money transfer one- and four-months following the end of the program. These outcomes will help us answer questions about the longer lasting effects of savings inducements on behavior.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Structure and Punitive Judgments: Final Study

sample.value: We will collect data from 1300 participants on Amazon's Mechanical Turk.

analyses.value:
We will first compute a linear mixed-effects model (LMEM) with personal need for structure (based on the 11-item scale developed by Neuberg and Newsom, 1993) and dependency salience (independence coded as 1, interdependence coded as 0) as fixed-effects, and with punishment judgments as the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects (random intercepts only).

Then, we will compute two follow-up LMEMs: one for the interdependence condition only, and the other for the independence condition only. In each model, PNS will be the fixed-effect, and punishment judgments will be the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects.

Finally, we will conduct a simple slopes analysis in the original fitted LMEM. We will test whether, at low levels of PNS (-1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero. And we will test whether, at high levels of PNS (+1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero.

outliers.value: The study will end with an attention check question: “Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took the survey seriously?” Participants will select one of five answers: (1) no, I was distracted; (2) no, I had trouble paying attention; (3) no, I didn’t not take the study seriously; (4) no, something else affected my participation negatively; or (5) yes. Participants will assured that their responses will not affect their payment or their eligibility for future studies. Only those participants who select (5) will be included in the analyses.

dependent.value: Participants will be presented with 12 moral principles, and for each one they will report how much a person who violates the principle should be punished on a 6-pt scale (1 = not at all, 6 = very much).

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions in a between-subjects fashion. We will manipulate the salience of participants’ feelings of independence or interdependence. To do so, participants randomly assigned to the “independence” condition will be asked to list two ways in which they are independent. In contrast, participants randomly assigned to the “interdependence” condition will be asked to list two groups they are dependent upon.

hypothesis.value: Is it the case that making salient the groups that people belong to and depend on, relative to making salient people’s unique individual qualities and independence, moderates the relationship between the personal need for structure and punitive judgments for moral principle violators.

We will first compute a linear mixed-effects model (LMEM) with personal need for structure (based on the 11-item scale developed by Neuberg and Newsom, 1993) and dependency salience (independence coded as 1, interdependence coded as 0) as fixed-effects, and with punishment judgments as the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects (random intercepts only).

Then, we will compute two follow-up LMEMs: one for the interdependence condition only, and the other for the independence condition only. In each model, PNS will be the fixed-effect, and punishment judgments will be the outcome variable. Participant and principle will be modeled as crossed random effects.

Finally, we will conduct a simple slopes analysis in the original fitted LMEM. We will test whether, at low levels of PNS (-1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero. And we will test whether, at high levels of PNS (+1 SD), the simple slope differs from zero.
